introduction.small: A stone's throw from the Don River in Toronto, White Lily Diner bets on healthy and fresh food, in the typical setting of a local restaurant.

paragraphs.text:
Five huge capital letters form the word diner on the facade. In Toronto, White Lily Diner showcases a very typically North American style, with partitioned tables, mustard yellow bench seats and an overall retro look. This old school appearance is complete with school chairs and old photos of the Queen East neighbourhood on the walls. Like any self-respecting diner, it is also open for breakfast, lunch or simple snacking.
The menu plays on classics, with a healthy twist thanks to fresh and local ingredients, in a farm-to-table philosophy. As another sign of goodwill toward healthier, comforting and more balanced diet, the fryer has been outlawed from the kitchen! Try the patty melts house specials, sandwiches filled with a beef patty and cheese sauce between two slices of hot bread. A deliciously regressive experience for grown-ups and a simple joy for youngsters.

White Lily Diner
678 Queen St E
Toronto
ON M4M 1G8

+1 (0)416 901 7800

www.whitelilydiner.ca

Menu: around 27 CAD

content.title: The Bata Shoe Museum, a museum dedicated to shoes

introduction.small: A perfect place for shoe lovers, Toronto's Bata Shoe Museum displays over 4,500 years of history with models from all over the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bata Shoe Museum, a museum dedicated to shoes

paragraphs.text:
A paradise of all kinds of shoes awaits you at Bata Shoe Museum, a sort of giant shoe box transformed into a work of art by architect Raymond Moriyama. Discover a collection of over a thousand models made out of wood, silk, fur and even hair. Various shapes, one more unlikely than the next, come from diverse periods and regions of the world. Shoes protect and support you, drag you outside in all types of weather, make you run, keep you warm and, today, strike a pose, au naturel.
In addition to three galleries where you can admire many temporary exhibitions, an entire room is dedicated to shoes worn by celebrities in the 20th century, such as Gandhi's leather sandals, Princess Diana's heels and Elton John's platform boots. The public owes this museum to businesswoman Sonja Bata, who has travelled to the most remote places on Earth to bring back unique pieces, symbols of different lifestyles and multiple cultures.

Bata Shoe Museum
327 Bloor Street West
Toronto ON M5S 1W7

+1 416 979 7799

www.batashoemuseum.ca

articles.topic: travel through time at black creek pioneer village

content.title: Travel through time at Black Creek Pioneer Village

introduction.small: Return to 19th century Toronto with the reconstruction of a village from the pioneer days, Black Creek.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Travel through time at Black Creek Pioneer Village

paragraphs.text:
In an authentic setting, the old-time Ontario countryside is reborn thanks to performances by actors in period costume. Since 1960, they have recreated life in this small village, as if it were frozen in time. Between shops, public establishments and farm buildings, count on visiting about forty homes! Some have been restored while others were completely rebuilt.
Immerse yourself in the daily life of these men and women of the past and observe their way of life. Actors are here to provide an unforgettable experience with shows and re-enactments in full-scale role-playing games. Artisans, tradesmen, printers, dressmakers… everything is done to make the experience seem more realistic. Try one of the trades, accompany musicians by playing an instrument while learning folk songs from the old times and taste real beer brewed in the Toronto area, light with sweet aromas of caramel and hops. You will have the opportunity to stay for half a day or a full day to take the time to walk around and enjoy your visit. For big eaters, it is possible to bring your own picnic!

Black Creek Pioneer Village
1000 Murray Ross Parkway
North York
Toronto ON M3J 2P3
Tel : +1 416 736 1733
www.blackcreek.ca

introduction.small: At the heart of Toronto's Entertainment District, Le Germain combines comfort and leading performance, elegant design, and works by artist James Lahey.

paragraphs.text:
Le Germain is appreciated as much for its sleek design as it is for its warm and personalized service.

With comfort as their only compass, the hotel designers have increased the luxurious amenities to include a library, an espresso bar, a large fireplace surrounded by couches in the great hall, and a roof terrace with a putting green and a training centre, open 24/7. Wood, warm colours and tulips are showcased in the 122 spacious rooms and suites that provide all the comfort and luxury imaginable. At the hotel restaurant, discover creative international cuisine, a reflection on Toronto's multicultural richness.

Popular with business travellers for its proximity to the Financial District, Le Germain is just a short walk from Lake Ontario. It is also just steps from the Rogers Centre, CN Tower, the Convention Centre and the TIFF Bell Lightbox.

Le Germain Hotel Toronto
30 Mercer St
Toronto
ON M5V 1H3

+1 866 345 9501

www.legermainhotels.com

Rooms: from 377 CAD

introduction.small: The Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) has about 40 galleries devoted to natural history and world culture within a varied and striking architectural showcase.

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1912, the Royal Ontario Museum, or ROM, originally displayed a neo-Romanesque Italian style. Its first expansion went for a neo-Byzantine look, with added Gothic Renaissance gargoyles.

But the most dramatic expansion remains that of the architect Daniel Libeskind, for the Renaissance ROM programme known as the Michael Lee-Chin Crystal, named for its prominent donor. This new deconstructionist addition of glass, steel, and brushed aluminium (2007), was inspired by the ROM's gems and minerals collections, which gives an avant-garde image to one of the largest museums in North America, whose assets include more than six million objects deposited throughout 40 galleries. The departments of natural history and world cultures are devoted to Anthropology, to the civilisations of the Near East and Asia, Art and Western Culture, Biodiversity, and to Earth Sciences and Paleobiology.

Children will likely prefer the James and Louise Temerty Galleries dedicated to the dinosaur age, or the scary cave inhabited by bats. Ideal for a family outing, the ROM is also renowned for its temporary exhibitions.

Royal Ontario Museum
100 Queens Park
Toronto
ON M5S 2C6

+1 (0)416 586 8000

www.rom.on.ca

introduction.small: Imagine Cannes or Venice celebrating cinema 365 days a year. This is what the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) offers on five floors at the Lightbox.

paragraphs.text:
The Lightbox is the name of the building where the activities of the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) are grouped. The festival takes place in September every year, but, unlike other festivals, it lives outside its two-week event span for…12 months. It features a host of activities for moviegoers, with multiple thematic retrospectives, exhibitions, and smaller events, like the Children's Film Festival (TIFF Kids International Film Festival), or one for teens called TIFF Next Wave Film Festival. Not to mention Canada's Top Ten Film Festival and the Human Rights Watch Film Festival.

Spread over five floors at the corner of King and John streets, this complex is in the heart of the entertainment district. It contains a huge three-story atrium, five screening rooms, two exhibition galleries, three learning studios, a student centre, a restaurant, a bistro, a gift shop, and a rooftop terrace which all celebrate the seventh art. In short, it is a mega film library that screens major films of cinematic history all day long.

TIFF Bell Lightbox
350 King St W
Toronto
ON M5V 3X5

+1 (0)416 599 8433

www.tiff.net

introduction.small: Ontario and New York State share the Niagara Falls, a Mecca of tourism for more than a century, but it is Canada that has the most beautiful falls: the Horse shoe.

paragraphs.text:
Less than a two-hour drive from downtown Toronto, Niagara Falls is one of the most famous natural sites in the world.

As part of a day trip, there are a number of different tours leaving from Toronto. You can also organize your own transportation either by direct train with VIA Rail, by train and bus with Go Transit, or by bus with Mega Bus. A ferry ride on the Maid of the Mist into the heart of the tumult of Horseshoe Falls is possible from April to September, which generally corresponds to the most crowded season. Go up the Skylon Tower at a height of 236 meters for a panoramic view, or dine in the tower's revolving restaurant on a summer weekend to see the dazzling fireworks.

Helicopter flights offer a particularly dramatic view of the falls. You can also test your nerves with Aero Cars, a cable car that crosses over the turbulent eddies.

+1 905 356 2241

www.niagaraparks.com

content.title: Hazelton Hotel: sophistication on every floor

introduction.small: Designed by renowned Canadian design duo Yabu Pushelberg, the Hazelton Hotel is the most exclusive and sophisticated hotel address in Toronto, from its rooms to its kitchens.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hazelton Hotel: sophistication on every floor

paragraphs.text:
George Yabu and Glenn Pushelberg first met on the benches of Ryerson University in Toronto. These Ontario natives, who are fans of ‘everything is possible', defy styles and transcend trends. They work primarily with major hotel chains and luxury brands.

At Hazelton, the 77 spacious and colourful rooms and suites are inspired by the Hollywood glamour of the 1940s, while the metal and granite add a contemporary touch. With an exceptional location in the heart of the University District, this grand hotel is close to most major museums and art galleries in Toronto. The Hazelton is also a patron of the arts, as its private collection has a number of unique works, including the stack of silvery suitcases signed by Bruno Billio (Nickel Plated Suitcases 2007), exhibited in the main hall.

The very mediates chef Mark McEwan, masterfully directs One, the hotel's restaurant, whose menu revisits the great Italian and French classics with the freshest local produce.

The Hazelton Hotel
118 Yorkville Ave
Toronto
ON M5R 1C4

+1 (0)416 963 6300

www.thehazeltonhotel.com

Rooms: from 449 CAD

introduction.small: This marvel of civil engineering was until 2010, the tallest free-standing structure in the world and also one of the city's most popular spots for marriage proposals.

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1976 (it took 40 months and cost 63 million dollars) and the tallest free-standing structure in the world for over 34 years, the iconic CN Tower overlooks the city from its 553.33 metres. After an ascent of 346 metres in 53 seconds, enjoy the panoramic views of the city from the LookOut level.

Dine at the upscale bistro Horizons, or play with your nerves on the all-glass observation deck, located more than 300 metres above ground. An independent ticket gives access to 33 additional floors as well as the SkyPod at 465 metres. Attached to a safety cable, thrill seekers can pit themselves against gravity on the Edge Walk, the narrow 1.5 metre wide ledge located 356 metres above the void.

End your visit at 360, the gourmet restaurant of the tower, known as a popular spot for marriage proposals, with its rotating floor that makes a full revolution in 72 minutes. This iconic Toronto landmark welcomes about 1.5 million visitors a year.

CN Tower
301 Front St W
Toronto
ON M5V 2T6

+1 (0)416 868 6937

www.cntower.ca/

introduction.small: On the 54th floor of the TD Bank Tower, Canoe is a flagship institution of gastronomy in Toronto, with a breath taking panorama over the city.

paragraphs.text:
Canoe has reigned supreme on the Toronto restaurant scene for more than a decade. The restaurant has recently undergone a several-million-dollar renovation and now offers resolutely contemporary and minimalist dining.

In the kitchen, the multi-award-winning chefs John Horne and Coulson Armstrong—harmoniously combining French and Canadian culinary techniques—have taken over the inventive and sophisticated stoves of Anthony Walsh, and are dedicated to Canadian specialties and local, seasonal ingredients. Discover the forest mushroom soup or the smoked fillets of duck breast in tea. For dessert, indulge in a must-try sugar pie. The Canoe also offers a most generous tasting menu, which is a great way to discover, with a group of friends, the subtle flavours and textures designed by the two chefs.

Canoe
66 Wellington St W
Toronto
ON M5K 1H6

+1 416 364 0054

www.canoerestaurant.com

Menu: around 100 CAD

content.title: Buca: the old world meets the new

introduction.small: The ultra-chic trattoria Buca hides in a private driveway in the Fashion District of Toronto. It is both a classic and modern address, celebrated for its local origins.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Buca: the old world meets the new

paragraphs.text:
With its menu of sometimes traditional and sometimes contemporary Italian flavors, Buca is one of the most famous restaurants in Toronto. Well-hidden in the Fashion District and full every night, Buca attracts a demanding clientele.
Take a seat in the main dining room around one of the long communal tables and, if possible, near the open kitchen to watch the team of chefs at work. A second, smaller dining room is perfect for an intimate or romantic evening. Among Buca's delicious Italian specialities, try the grilled meats, crispy wood-fired pizzas and homemade pastas.
The service is provided by a friendly and comely team composed solely of men, all Italian of course, which adds a charming southern touch.

Buca
604 King St W
ON M5V 1M6

+1 (0)416 865 1600

www.buca.ca

Menu: around 30 CAD

introduction.small: A hotel, restaurant, and place of festivity all at once, despite the small size of some rooms, the Drake and its vintage decor have redefined the boutique hotel in Toronto.

paragraphs.text:
More than a hotel, the Drake combines a multitude of meeting places and social life under one roof. In addition to a boutique 19-room hotel designed by John Tong, one of the three designers of the famous 3rd Uncle Design team, it features a beautiful lounge, the open-air Sky Yard rooftop bar (a plus for smokers), a restaurant, a sushi bar, a café with terrace, and a General Store a popular concept store that offers a specialized selection of design objects for the home.

In the basement, the concert hall has even hosted several big names in music, including the American singer, Beck. During performance nights, you may hear some noise from your room, so if you can't beat 'em, join ‘em.

The Drake is located in the centre of West Queen West, the area that houses galleries, restaurants, and the most fashionable design shops in Toronto. Aromatherapy, shiatsu massage, fitness, yoga it is a classic bourgeois-bohemian address.

The Drake Hotel
1150 Queen Street West, Toronto
ON M6J 1J3

+1 (0)416 531 5042

www.thedrakehotel.ca

Rooms: from 309 CAD

content.title: Ice hockey in the city centre

introduction.small: The ACC or Air Canada Centre, also known as the ‘Hangar', is the arena (62,000 square meters) for Canada's national sport, ice hockey, located right downtown on Bay Street.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ice hockey in the city centre

paragraphs.text:
Ice hockey, Canada's national sport is a sight not to be missed. The AAC (Air Canada Centre) complex in the heart of the city is the scene of matches for the city's top team, the Toronto Maple Leafs. A match at the ‘Hangar' during the season, which runs from September to April, is a must on any visit to Toronto.

To get the most out of a match in a refined setting, dine at the club of the same name, and watch the game from the bar, or opt for the more exclusive Platinum Club, which has a wine list with over 500 references. Need to refresh your knowledge of hockey? Visit the Hall of Fame, located a few kilometres north. Dedicated to the legends of the sport, it offers souvenirs, trophies, and players' jerseys worn during historical games, and obviously, the famous Stanley Cup.

Finally, do not miss the opportunity to score a goal at the exhibition ‘Be a Player', or stop a puck launched by Wayne Gretzky, simulated by computer.

Air Canada Centre
40 Bay St
Toronto
ON M5J 2X2

Hockey Hall of Fame
30 Yonge St
Toronto
ON M5E 1X8

+1 416 815 5500

www.theaircanadacentre.com

content.title: The Planet Traveler Hostel: sleep while respecting the environment

introduction.small: The Planet Traveler is a ‘green hotel', an eco-hostel, where you can stay in environmentally friendly dorms or private rooms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Planet Traveler Hostel: sleep while respecting the environment

paragraphs.text:
Housed in a building that was formerly abandoned, The Planet Traveler today offers elegant, opulent rooms and boasts of using ‘less electrical power than a four-slice toaster' daily.

It's impossible not to notice the string of solar and photovoltaic panels that adorn its roof, which give the building a distinctively futuristic appearance. The whole structure was designed and built with the goal of greater respect for the environment, and the building includes geothermal temperature control, movement sensors to regulate lighting, and a water-recovery system. It is a model for ‘green hotels' in North America and around the world, and a conscientiously green proposal that is both elegant and spacious. It is also ideally located at the crossroads of Kensington Market and the trendy, bright-coloured bars of Little Italy.

After a long day exploring the city, take a walk up to the rooftop bar, open until midnight, and watch the sun dip into Lake Ontario.

The Planet Traveler
357 College St, Toronto
ON M5T 1S5

+1 647 352 8747

www.theplanettraveler.com

Rooms: from 57 CAD

introduction.small: The Gladstone Hotel is a quirky and affordable boutique hotel of 37 rooms and suites that are all different, in the chic-bohemian neighbourhood of West Queen West in Toronto.

paragraphs.text:
Housed in a historic Victorian building with high ceilings, the Gladstone was designed by architect George Miller, with the help of local artists and designers. Prepare yourself for an eye-catching design, full-on colour, and a profusion of works of art. The original arched windows, exposed brick walls, and the still-working, manually operated elevator from 1904, are charmingly reminiscent of the building's history.

Yet the 37 rooms and suites, each designed by a different artist, are resolutely contemporary. The Biker Roomtakes up the theme of the movie Easy Rideras revisited by Andrew Harwood, while the four-room suite Canadian Room, both kitsch and romantic, evokes nature and the Canadian landscape with its cedar-wood panelling, the pervasiveness of wool, its railway landscape, and its Trophy chandelier... It is a universe created by The Big Stuff team, who also worked for the Drake Hotel and Jenny Francis Design.

In the hotel lobby, the Melody Bar is the perfect place to mingle with members of Toronto's independent arts scene.

The Gladstone Hotel
1214 Queen St W, Toronto
ON M6J 1J6

+1 (0)416 531 4635

www.gladstonehotel.com

Rooms: from 360 CAD

content.title: The fantastic Art Gallery of Ontario: enhanced by Frank Gehry

introduction.small: The Museum of Fine Arts and Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO) is a major institution where big international exhibitions are held, one after another, behind a facade reconfigured by Frank Gehry.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The fantastic Art Gallery of Ontario: enhanced by Frank Gehry

paragraphs.text:
The Museum of Fine Arts of Ontario holds the largest collection of Canadian art in the world with more than 80,000 works spanning from the first century to the present. It also celebrates the art of Africa, Europe, and Oceania.

The building stands out for its avant-garde architecture (Frank Gehry), composed of glass, steel, and wood, which creates a space bathed in light and is alone worth a visit. The Museum of Fine Arts has many masterpieces, and is home to works by Henri Matisse, Henry Moore, Georgia O'Keeffe, Salvador Dalí, Piet Mondrian, and Vincent van Gogh.

Among the permanent collections of the Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO), is the formidable Thomson Collection, whose centrepiece is The Massacre of the Innocents (1611-1612) by Rubens. The great art lover and Canadian billionaire Kenneth Thomson acquired it in 2002 at Sotheby's for £49.5m, before donating it to the AGO in 2008.

Art Gallery of Ontario
317 Dundas St W
Toronto
ON M5T 1G4

+1 (0)416 979 6648

www.ago.net

introduction.small: Architecture, graphic design, fashion, and industrial design light up in the former Toronto Stock Exchange building, which has become the Design Exchange, Canada's only museum dedicated to design and innovation.

paragraphs.text:
Both a museum and an active promoter of Canadian design; the Design Exchange is installed in the city's former stock exchange, the impressive Toronto Stock Exchange building. The permanent collection of the Design Exchange (DX) covers everything from fashion to furniture, through household items, electronics, and lighting, since 1945.

Promoting Canadian avant-garde design is engineered through more than 50 exhibitions, conferences, and events each year. A non-profit organisation and the only national museum dedicated to design, the Design Exchange invites you to explore the country's history through a hyper creative perspective.

The president of the DX, Shauna Levy, is an enterprising visionary and, in just four years, will be able to give the institution an international dimension. ‘Design is ubiquitous' she says, ‘it is the cornerstone of society… It is as much about addressing basic human needs, such as post-disaster housing or caring for an aging population, as it is about luxury goods and novel experiences.'

Design Exchange
234 Bay St
Toronto
ON M5K 1B2

+1 (0)416 363 6121

www.dx.org

content.title: Mildred's Temple Kitchen: cuisine in a designer warehouse

introduction.small: At the heart of Liberty Village, Mildred's Temple Kitchen revisits small and large Canadian culinary specialities in a welcoming designer space.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mildred's Temple Kitchen: cuisine in a designer warehouse

paragraphs.text:
Mildred's Temple Kitchen is an ode to friendship, food, and the simple things in life. Donna Dooher, the famous star chef of the restaurant, shares her time between her open kitchen, television—where she hosts the very popular Cookworks show—and the direction of Restaurants Canada, which represents approximately 30,000 restaurants, bars, catering companies, and other food service providers. Adept at comforting cuisine with gourmet touches, chef Dooher offers a small menu and great specialties, ranging from cheddar and roasted garlic biscuits to MTK homemade hamburgers filled with onions and aioli on a whole wheat bun, served with green vegetables or fries. Poutines are obviously a landmark. Set in a beautifully renovated warehouse in Liberty Village, with chic industrial style interiors (designer: Brian Brownlie) softened by bouquets of wild flowers arranged in coloured glass jars, Mildred's offers a beautiful terrace in the summer for its not-to-be-missed Sunday brunch.

Mildred's Temple Kitchen
85 Hanna Ave
ON M6K 3S3

+1 (0)416 588 5695

www.templekitchen.com

Menu: around 30 CAD

introduction.small: A prestigious contemporary, internationally renowned art institution, Power Plant Gallery in Harbour front Centre is open as much to artists as it is to the public, and 100% free of charge.

paragraphs.text:
The Power Plant Gallery is a huge post-industrial space, located in a former coal power station.

Both a paradise for emerging artists and a must for contemporary art lovers, the Power Plant Gallery is a hub of contemporary Canadian art, with temporary exhibitions that are sometimes thematic and sometimes dedicated to a single artist. It is 30% financed by public funds, and the balance by the prosperity of the city (corporate philanthropy). The Power Plant access is free has been directed since 2011 by the charismatic Quebecoise, Gaetane Verna, a graduate of the Sorbonne and a woman for whom ‘art is constantly renewing our perception of the world'. With no permanent collection, the Power Plant welcomes new talents on the artistic scene.

Founded in 1987, the institution is also famous for its concerts, lectures, film screenings, and avant-garde publications.

The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery
231 Queens Quay W
Toronto
ON M5J 2G8

+1 (0)416 973 4949

www.thepowerplant.org

content.title: St. Lawrence Market: a paradise for gourmets

introduction.small: Toronto's iconic St. Lawrence Market offers excellent opportunities for affordable gastronomic feasts, with a jazz background.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: St. Lawrence Market: a paradise for gourmets

paragraphs.text:
Voted best market in the world by the National Geographic, the St. Lawrence Market's frenetic and exuberant atmosphere is a multi-flavoured culinary adventure.

Housed in a 19th century brick building, this gourmet paradise is divided into two sections. To the south, more than 200 merchants sell gourmet products, while the north building is filled every Saturday morning with fresh farm products, a tradition that has endured for 300 years. With its lively atmosphere, jazz musicians, and spicy aromas, the St. Lawrence Market is the perfect place to spend a morning.

Arrive hungry to enjoy free tastings of pastries just out of the oven. Outside, benches and tables are available for a picnic by the river. It's up to you to choose between an improvised feast of croissants and homemade lemon jam or a gourmet meal with wine, freshly shucked oysters, and homemade pasta.

St. Lawrence Market
93 Front Street East
Toronto
ON M5E 1C3

+1 (0)416 392 7219

www.stlawrencemarket.com
